text: - AI serves as an enabler
for how myeloma patients
and patients navigate their journey,

and it is not necessarily
replacing the human connection
but really strengthening it

by allowing patients to
make a more personalized,
accessible, and effective decisions.
(light upbeat music)

- Welcome to another episode
of "Data Strategy Unravelled."
I'm your host, Khendr'a Reid,

Principal Data and Gen AI
Strategy Specialist here at AWS.
Now, if you've been watching our videos
for a little while now,
we had one a few weeks ago on healthcare

and the role that data and AI
is playing in that industry.
Now, in that video,
we talked a little bit about Omada Health

and some of the things that
they're doing in that space
when it comes to data analytics.
But we really wanted to double-click
into that healthcare space
and bring in another customer testimonial
in how AWS has partnered with them
in order to improve those patient outcomes
for their patients.
And to talk about this,
we have the CEO

of the International
Myeloma Foundation, IMF,
Yelak Biru.
Hey Yelak, how you doing?
- Good, thank you so much for having me.
- Yeah, we're happy to have you here.

We're really grateful
for you to join us today.

How about you tell us a
little bit about yourself,
maybe where you're joining us from

before we get into some of
these questions we have?
- Absolutely, my name is Yelak Biru.

I have the pleasure of
serving as president and CEO
of the International Myeloma Foundation.
When you said IMF,
what came to my mind

was Impossible Mission Force,
(Khendr'a laughing)
but sometimes the work we do sounds
like an impossible mission.
It is a nonprofit organization
that has been in existence for 35 years.

This coming October, actually,
we'll celebrate our 35 year.

But this organization
is near and dear to me

because I'm also a
multiple myeloma patient,
diagnosed at age 25, almost 30 years ago,

and was told that I only
will be able to live two
or three years,

and I'll for sure will
be dead before I turn 30.
So I'm happy to join you, really, in this,

my 30th anniversary of
living with multiple myeloma.
- Wow. Wow.
Yeah, we're happy to have you
and I'm sure some of our viewers here

probably didn't think
you were older than 30
the way you way you look today, right?
(Khendr'a laughing)
- Right, right.
(Khendr'a laughing)

- So, you know, the reason
that we have you here
is to kind of talk about,
you know, you being the CEO,
you know, you partner with AWS,
specifically our data strategy team,

and your vision that
you have for data and AI
and how it can help your organization.
So, let's kind of jump into this.
And so, lets lay out what is your vision

when it comes to data, AI,
maybe even generative AI now,
and patient care when it comes to myeloma?

- You know, as a myeloma
patient who, I just mentioned,

has lived almost 30
years with this disease,

and I call myself also a
recovering computer scientist
and data analyst
because I worked in the for-profit world
for almost 25 years,
this is personal to me, right?

I have experienced
firsthand the complexities
of having to navigate treatment decision,
understanding new therapies,
and really navigating complex landscapes
of healthcare here in the US.

So when you ask me about my
vision for data, AI, and gen AI,
as a myeloma patient,
it really is to be able to transform

how patients access,
how patients understand,

and how patients act on
critical health information.

Ultimately, with the
goal of improving outcome
and quality of life for myeloma patients.
If you allow me,

I want to explain it in three
or four different areas.

The first one is around
learning prescription.

All of us have different ways
of consuming information,

different levels of
technical understanding
and health literacy,

and being able to create
a learning prescription
using AI systems

can really support patients
make informed choices.
The second one

is diseases like multiple
myeloma, cancers incurable,
affect different populations differently.

Different people with different
socioeconomic situations,

they are impacted by myeloma
and the outcomes are different.

So, I really want to use
AI, data, and analytics

and gen AI to provide
equitable access to information
so patients are able
to navigate a culturally relevant,

language adaptive, and
literacy conscious resources
as they navigate their myeloma care.
In multiple myeloma,
like other diseases also,

shared decision making
is really important.
Being able to be the person at the table

when your doctor, when your
healthcare professional
is making the decision

for what your next best
treatment should be.
So, myeloma patients
can leverage AI and gen AI types of tools

in order to enhance their
shared decision making.
So I think, really,
if I want to summarize this,
is AI serves as an enabler
for how myeloma patients
and patients navigate their journey.

And it is not necessarily
replacing the human connection,
but really strengthening it by making...

Allowing patients to
make a more personalized,
accessible, and effective decisions.

- Yeah, I mean, really
what you laid out there

is a lot of what we've
talked about on this channel,
how the technology is really an enabler
for the value that you want to provide.

A lot of times we're talking
about business value,

but here you're talking
about that patient value
that you're providing using technology.
So yeah, that's really great there.

And I know that our team,
the Data Strategy team,
partnered with you and your team,
you know, patients and caregivers

on, you know, our D2E
design thinking process
and helping you to really sort of envision
how that data and AI

can really start to create
that better patient experience
for your patients.
How has that, you know,
we went through that process,

that data strategy process,
I guess you could say.
How has that benefited a lot of
what you're talking about here

when it comes to the initiatives
that you had with IMF?
- Yeah, maybe a little over two years ago,
we were really able
and fortunate enough to benefit
from yours, Tanya's, Kelly's,
and many other D2E leaders
within AWS's knowledge, experience,
and also technical abilities.
So for me,

D2E, the Data-Driven
Everything methodology
is really a very powerful framework
that, as you mentioned earlier,

helps us align the business
and the technical priorities.
As you mentioned,

technology is not for
the sake of technology
unless you are AWS

or some other tech company.
- [Khendr'a] (laughs) Yeah.

- But if you are a small
business and nonprofit like us,
we really need to use technology
to help accelerate the business.

So, I think that the
biggest benefit for us
of the D2E methodology
was really identifying clear problems
and stating measurable objectives
and defining the benefits

of data-driven solutions.
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.

- So, we knew what we
can do with technology,

but we didn't necessarily
have that clear definition

of what the problems that
we're trying to solve was,
and what was our measurable objective,

and how we achieved that.
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.

- I think the other benefit
of the D2E methodology
and the team that AWS was able to assemble
is really, it allowed us

to bring all of the key
stakeholders from our side.

We brought patients, we
brought care partners,
we brought clinicians

and key opinion leaders in
the field of multiple myeloma.
We brought nurses,

we brought IMF team members
and other decision makers.

And it allowed us really
to co-create the solution,

agree the problem,
prioritize the outcomes,
and be able to co-create the solutions
during that two or three days.
But there was a lot of pre-work

and there was a lot of
post-work that was done.
So for me, really,

creating problems, I'm sorry,
understanding the problems,
but also creating the solutions

that are very near and dear
to the myeloma patients

and the myeloma community
was really, really key.
- Yeah, and what you mentioned

about bringing together
those different personas,

you know, before I actually
joined a team, et cetera,
and I learned about this methodology.

You know, I thought it
was so fascinating, right?

Being able to understand what
these different personas are,

how they see the data, how
they're interacting with data,

the challenges that
they might have, right?
It really helps you understand
what they go through in their day to day
and how to help solve for that

and understand what is
the overall challenge

that we wanna solve to help
benefit these different personas

with that overall solution
we're driving here.
And so, I know that-
- It also can drive...

- Uh-huh?
- So, what it also allowed us
was bring all those stakeholders and say,
"Who should we be creating

these tech solutions for?"
- [Khendr'a] Exactly, yeah.
- So, it allowed us
to specifically identify
three key personas
that we wanted to create this,

what we are calling the
Myeloma Knowledge Platform,
which is really a personalized,

data-driven guidance methodology
for myeloma patients.

So, we had newly diagnosed
multiple myeloma patients
that we identified as a persona.

We also, at the IMF, wanted
to become data-driven,
and we identified ourselves

as one of the personas we
want to have the solution for.
But the third persona that we created
was the community physicians.

Community physicians are
where 70 plus percent

of the myeloma patients
get diagnosed, get treated,

and get all their care
for multiple myeloma.

But those physicians also treat
10, 12, 15 different types
of other cancers,
and the landscape of multiple myeloma

is exponentially and significantly
becoming more complex
with the discovery of new drugs

and the bringing to
market of new therapies.
So, we really also need to make sure
that our solution was going to be able

and help to transform myeloma
care for myeloma patients
wherever they were receiving care.

- Yeah, and so, you
mentioned there a little bit
about the platform that you all built
coming out of that workshop,
so let's talk a little bit about that.

You know, I think there was a
chat bot component there too,
to help augment some of the services
of the IMF support team.
Can you talk a little bit about that
and kind of where you all are now
since you've gone through that process?
- Absolutely, so the thing,
I call it the thing we came up with
when worked through D2E was AWS,
is the Myeloma Knowledge Platform.
It is really allowing us

to bring all of the patient
experiences with us,
like in an omnichannel way.
So, the way we approach this

is AWS knows about their
customers very well.

When you go to Amazon and
you are able to purchase
when you want to purchase something.

Why can't we do the same
thing for myeloma patients?

We want to know when they
attended the myeloma seminar.

We want to know what they
consumed on our website.

We want to know the questions
they asked our info line,
not because we want to be creepy,

but because we really want
to be able to understand
and provide learnings

to the next myeloma patient
that looks like them
and is traveling their experience.

So, the manifestation of that
was creating of a data lake,

what we are calling MKP,
Myeloma Knowledge Platform.
But on top of that,

putting a gen AI platform
on top of it called Myelo.
Myelo is really a personalized assistant,
like Alexa,

for myeloma patients that
is able to engage them

and understand the questions
that they're asking
and be able to provide the answers
in terms that they're able to understand.
Since our launch of Myelo in January,
I think actually was January 12,

we have had over 20,000
interactions from Myelo,

and the success story
is really outstanding.
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.

- Yesterday, we spoke
someone from the Middle East
and they say they have family members,

but they are very alone
in their myeloma journey,
so they really interact with Myelo.

We interacted with somebody
here from the Los Angeles area
that has recently lost their spouse,

but they progressed from the
early precursor condition
of multiple myeloma to full blown myeloma,

and they were able really
to interact with Myelo

and Myelo was able to
answer their question.
Really, the most transformational,
or I think the most insightful evidence
of how Myelo is helping patients
is there is a patient and his care partner

that are very, very
knowledgeable about myeloma.
They're actually like a super advocate.
But they said one night on a Friday,
they got a response

from one of their test
results they were receiving
on MyChart.

And they were worried
that they had relapsed
or the patient had relapsed.
They went to Myelo,

they cut and tested that
question and the result,

and Myelo assured them
that they have not relapsed

and explained what that
test results meant,

and gave them really the
peace of mind they needed
over that weekend

until they met with
their doctor on Monday.

So, we are leveraging
the success of Myelo now
to ideate and create Myelo MD.
As I mentioned earlier,
you know, 60 to 70% of myeloma patients
are diagnosed and get treated

in the community hospitals.
- [Khendr'a] Mm-hm.
- So, and this...

Oncologists treat a lot
of other myeloma patients.
So, the premise behind Myelo MD
is it will be able

to be fed the information
about the patient
that's sitting in front of the physician
and allow them to be able to understand
what the next best treatment option

for that patient that's
sitting in front of them is.
So really, leveraging data,
leveraging artificial intelligence,

it really is enabling both
patients and clinicians
to make a very informed decision
in their treatment and treatment guidance.
- Yeah, I mean,
you all are really transforming not just,
you know, in the myeloma space,

but really healthcare in
general, I think, right?

In the capabilities that
you're providing, right?
Because what you're doing here

could easily be provided
in other areas as well.
And you know,
we have some viewers most likely
that probably have the same vision as you

when it comes to being able
to leverage data and AI

for, I guess you could
say for good, right?
You know, they see that vast opportunity
when it comes to the tech and data
and wanting to be able to share that

and bring others along
with them on that vision.
Can you share any learnings

or guidance for these other
organizations or leaders

that aspire to be kind
of where you all are now?
- Absolutely, and as you said,

a lot of other nonprofit
organizations have reached out
to us saying,

"How do we get started?"
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.
- I think the key is really understanding

what we talked about at the
beginning of this podcast.
It is not about the technology itself.

It really is about the problem
you are trying to solve,
so being crystal clear

about what is the problem
that you are trying to solve,
start by really understanding the needs
of the people we serve,
whether it is in the healthcare area,
or homelessness, or whatever it may be.

In our case, it was about
patients, caregivers,
and the doctors that treat them.
So, that is really one.
The second portion for us

was really fostering an
overall data-driven culture.

We have to pay and we are
still paying our tech debt.
I don't think we, as an organization,
we really understood the challenges
with bad data or dirty data
or classify it how you may want

to classify it.
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.

- So us, really truly
peeling back the onion,
going back to the source of the data
and ensuring that the data

that's feeding the
Myeloma Knowledge Platform

in our data lake is clean
was really important.
And in general, also us saying,
"This is how we have done it,"
to us saying that,
"This is now what the data is telling us,"

is a transformation that
we are still undergoing.

And I believe a lot of other
organizations really need

to undergo as well.
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.

- I think the other element
is the human element.

We briefly touched on
how data or technology
is not going to replace the human.
There is fear within the organization
that we have to alleviate that,

we are not bringing this
technology to replace any humans.
We are bringing this technology
to really enable the humans
that are supporting the patients.
So, patients in some cases
can become self-servent in some areas
and allow our team members

to be able to address the
most complex questions
that our patients have.
So,
Myelo and our chat bot in general
and our mindset shift
towards this data-driven approach
has really been transformational.
And the last element I'll bring here
is don't really underestimate
the power of collaboration.

I, for example, never
thought we'll collaborate
with an organization like AWS
or some of our other collaborators today

that have allowed us
to bring Myelo to life

and allowing us to really
sustain and think through
what the next transformation of Myelo MD
or what the, you know,
next transformation of this AI-enabled,

technology-enabled journey
for myeloma patients would be.

- Yeah, I think that's
an interesting point
that you mentioned there
'cause I think a lot of companies struggle

with the collaboration internally
with these siloed teams.
But what you're saying here is,
you know, companies collaborate
with other organizations, right?
To take the learnings from one another

and collaborate together
to build those outcomes
that they both are envisioning

can be really powerful, just
as you all have done as well.
Yelak, thank you so much

for taking the time to
join the channel today

and provide these gems
that you've given us.
Especially our viewers,
I'm sure a lot of them found it insightful
and inspirational, I know I have.

And we hope to maybe have
you back in the future

when you've continued to
build out this platform,
you can talk through some of the things
that you've done so far.

- Thank you so much.
- All right.

- Thank you for having me.
- Thank you.
